Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Quill 2.0: A Powerful Rich Text Editor for the Web â€” A major release and significant modernization for the open source WYSIWYG editor. In Announcing Quill 2.0, we learn about Quillâ€™s transition to TypeScript and improved use of modern browser features, but thereâ€™s more going on too, such as its ESM packaging. Want to play with some code? Thereâ€™s a playground.

Slab Inc.

Airbnb's Extensive JavaScript Style Guide â€” Itâ€™s been years since we mentioned this popular, opinionated style guide, but it keeps getting little tweaks and repairs and remains a handy resource nonetheless.

Airbnb

WorkOS: Enterprise-Grade Auth for Modern SaaS Apps â€” WorkOS supports both the foundational auth and complex enterprise features like SSO. It provides flexible and easy-to-use APIs, helping companies like Vercel, Loom, and Webflow become Enterprise Ready. Best of all, WorkOS User Management supports up to 1 million MAUs for free.

WorkOS sponsor

Upgrading jQuery: Working Towards a Healthy Web â€” jQuery remains all over the Web, and the jQuery team and OpenJS Foundation have joined forces to make sure sites get up to date. Their 'Healthy Web Checkup' tool can tell you if the version of jQuery on a site is outdated (.. most likely 'yes' ğŸ˜…).

Timmy Willison (jQuery)

Biome v1.7: Faster Formatting and Linting, Now Even Easier to Migrate To â€” Biome is an increasingly compelling, all-in-one JavaScript, TypeScript and JSX Prettier-compatible formatter and linter. v1.7 makes it easier to migrate to from ESLint and Prettier, can emit machine-readable JSON reports, and has some rule updates.

Biome Core Team

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ¤¡ â–¶ï¸ Interview with Senior JS Developer 2024 is a satirical(?) take on the state of modern development and increasingly complex ecosystems. Watch to either laugh or cry. (6 minutes.)

  • ğŸ“º Bartek Szwej has put together a list of 300 JavaScript-related videos from the past year, ordered by their YouTube view count.

  • f(x) (a.k.a. fx) is a great CLI tool for viewing JSON data. It now includes a JS engine so you can process JSON with JavaScript one-liners at the terminal, too.

  • Joyee Cheung shares a trip report from Node.js's latest collaboration summit, touching on the topics the Node team is thinking about lately.

  • The folks at Deno go into depth about how they built JSR, the newest JavaScript registry, and how it can operate at scale.

  • "Much faster JSX element creation" is on the way for React developers.

ğŸ“’ Articles & Tutorials

Building a CLI from Scratch with TypeScript and oclif â€” oclif is a mature CLI tool development framework maintained by Salesforce. This tutorial goes from zero to something that works.

Josh Cunningham

Qwik vs. Next.js: Which is Right for Your Next Web Project? â€” A point by point faceoff between Qwik vs Next.js and why the author thinks Qwik takes the gold medal.

Samuel Mendenhall (Cisco)

RAG to Riches Developer Quest â€” Interact with AI-enhanced bots and learn to build your own RAG chatbot with Atlas Vector Search and Node.js.

MongoDB sponsor

CSS in React Server Components â€” An exploration of compatibility issues between React Server Components and CSS-in-JS libraries like styled-components.

Josh W Comeau

Profiling Node.js Performance with Chrome's Performance Panel â€” Learn how to profile Node performance with Chrome's Performance panel. (The JS Profiler is going away in Chrome 124, so you'll need to become familiar with the newer approach.)

Chrome for Developers

ğŸ“„ Keeping Up with the Node-ish Ecosystem â€“ How Mux updated its legacy Node SDK to work with new JS runtimes. Dylan Jhaveri (Mux)

  • Val Town is a fantastic online platform for writing and deploying TypeScript functions right from the browser and has just raised $5.5m in funding.

Using AI-Powered Autofix to Fix Your Broken Code â€” Join Sentry live on April 25th, to preview Autofix and learn how we are using ML to prioritize issues and alerts.

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Madge 7.0: Create Graphs From Your Module Dependencies â€” A tool for generating a visual graph of module dependencies, finding circular dependencies, and discovering other useful info.

Patrik Henningsson

PythonMonkey: A JavaScript Engine in the Python VM â€” If you need to use Python but also want to run JavaScript, this gives you a way to do it with the Mozilla SpiderMonkey JS engine embedded into the Python runtime with Python providing the host environment.

Distributive

â¤ï¸ Loving console.log Is Easy, but Hate ğŸ˜¡ Losing Context to View Messy Output â€” Developer productivity tools Wallaby.js, Quokka.js and Console Ninja show console.log values and errors right next to your code.

Wallaby Team sponsor

Faces.js: A Library for Generating Vector-Based Cartoon Faces â€” The end results are somewhat reminiscent of how the Nintendo Wii generates random Miis. Faces are drawn as SVGs with each also represented by a JavaScript object so you can draw them again later.

ZenGM

Color.js 0.5: 'Letâ€™s Get Serious About Color' â€” A fantastic library for working with colors in the browser, following the latest specs. Itâ€™s even been used by browsers to test their CSS Color 4/5 implementations.

Lea Verou and Chris Lilley

Preview.js: Preview UI Components Instantly in Your IDE â€” Namely, VS Code or JetBrain IDEs, out of the box. Compatible with components built for React, Vue, Svelte and Solid.

Zenc Labs Pty

Kosko: Organize Kubernetes Manifests in JavaScript â€” Version 4.1 has just been released with a new plugin system.

Tommy Chen

Transformational Auth & Identity | Userfront â€” "Compared to our previous experiences in the security/auth space, Userfront is an order of magnitude simpler to use."

Userfront sponsor

  • Mikro ORM 6.2 â€“ TypeScript ORM for Node.js based on Data Mapper. SQL Server and libSQL/Turso join the list of supported databases.

  • Rspack 0.6 â€“ Fast Rust-based web bundler.

  • Pixi.js 8.1 â€“ The fast WebGL and WebGPU 2D graphics engine switches back to WebGL by default due to immature browser support.

  • Jotai 2.8 â€“ Simple, flexible state management for React.

  • DOMPurify 2.5 â€“ Fast, tolerant XSS sanitizer for HTML and SVG.

  • Reveal.js 5.1 â€“ Framework for building presentations in HTML.

  • Xterm.js 5.5 â€“ Create terminal experiences on the Web.

  • TIFF 6.0 â€“ Pure JS TIFF image decoder.

  • Shiki 1.3 â€“ Powerful syntax highlighter.

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

A Proposal to Add Signals to JavaScript â€” A (very) early stage proposal for bringing a new feature to ECMAScript/JavaScript: signals! The proposal brings aboard ideas from a swathe of popular frameworks and aims to align everyone and get us on the same page when it comes to working with state and making updates based upon changes to state. Rob writes more about the proposal here.

Rob Eisenberg and Daniel Ehrenberg

Build a RAG Chatbot App with MongoDB and Node.js â€” Embark on the RAG to Riches Developer Quest â€” a month of innovation, learning, and exclusive rewards awaits you. Youâ€™ll interact with AI-enhanced bots and learn how to build your own with Atlas Vector Search and Node.js. Register now!

MongoDB sponsor

JS-Torch: A PyTorch-Like Library for JavaScript â€” Pythonâ€™s PyTorch is one of the gold standards amongst machine learning libraries, but this project brings some of its features directly into the JavaScript world. Hereâ€™s a live browser-based demo. Early days but this could become a big deal.

Eduardo Leao

Bun 1.1 Released: Now Supports Windows Too â€” With the lighthearted codename of Bundows, the alternative server side runtime now runs directly on Windows 10 and up (plus WSL, macOS and Linux, of course). This is a key step in its adoption, with even features like Bun Shell happy on Windows out of the box. Node compatibility continues to improve with support for node:http2 and IPC support between Bun and Node processes.

The Entire Bun Team

IN BRIEF:

  • Samuel GroÃŸ of the V8 team explains the V8 Sandbox, a security mechanism designed to prevent memory corruption in the V8 engine impacting other memory in the process.

  • Dexie.js is a popular wrapper for IndexedDB and its creator has launched Dexie Cloud, a platform to store and synchronize data between apps.

  • Svelte's Rich Harris is 'shaken up' after a misunderstanding around 'self-closing' HTML tags and their effect on Svelte.

  • ğŸ¤¡ There was a curious JS-themed April Fools prank where a .js TLD for domain names was 'announced'. Sadly, it's not true, but there is js.org if you want something vaguely similar.

  • An official update on the merging of Angular and Wiz.

RELEASES:

  • Deno 1.42 â€“ The alternative JS runtime adds first class support for JSR and improves Node.js compatibility further.

  • Babylon.js 7 (homepage) â€“ Key release of the popular rendering engine.

  • Node.js April 3 Security Releases â€“ Includes 18.20.1, 20.12.1 & 21.7.2.

  • Docusaurus 3.2 â€“ Popular content/docs site generator.

  • Gulp 5.0

ğŸ“’ Articles & Tutorials

What Even Is a JSON Number? â€” Despite the presence of standards around JSON, the answer is more complicated than youâ€™d think, particularly when it comes to interfacing with other ecosystems and languages that arenâ€™t JavaScript.

Brian Terlson

The History of JS Interop in Dart â€” About twelve years ago, Google introduced Dart, a language which initially seemed set to take over a lot of JavaScriptâ€™s use cases, but which eventually found its own niche (notably with Flutter). JS interoperability has remained important, though, and with Dart 3.3 has gotten significantly better.

Sigmund Cherem (Google)

Everything I've Learned About Scaling Designs Systems (With Examples) â€” I've learned a lot about what it takes to build, maintain, and scale design systems initiatives at large companies.

StackBlitz sponsor

The BFCache Explained â€” The back/forward cache (â€˜bfcacheâ€™) is a browser optimization that makes going back and forward in the browser a faster experience â€“ itâ€™s been present for years and usually leaves you alone as a JavaScript developer, but there are things worth being aware of.

Sabatino Masala

Running OCR Against PDFs and Images Directly in the Browser â€” A look behind the scenes at creating a simple tool using JavaScript to perform OCR against images and PDFs dragged on to the page.

Simon Willison

The Easy Way to Access the Last Array Element
Ignace Maes

A Comparison of JavaScript CRDTs
Alexis MÃ©taireau

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Cally: Small, Feature-Rich Calendar Components â€” A collection of open-source calendar components for selecting single dates or date ranges. Framework-agnostic, themeable, localizable, and accessible (it even has an accessibility statement showing its commitment to this area).

Nick Williams

ğŸ“Š Counterscale: Scalable Web Analytics You Can Run on Cloudflare â€” A simple web analytics tracker and dashboard thatâ€™s designed to be easy to deploy and maintain by hosting it on Cloudflare (for free too, up to a certain level).

Ben Vinegar

Product for Engineers: A Newsletter Helping Flex Your Product Muscle â€” Subscribe for free to get curated advice on building great products and best practices of top startups.

PostHog sponsor

ğŸµ Tonal.js: A Music Theory Library â€” Packed with functions to manipulate tonal elements of music like notes, intervals, chords, scales, modes, and keys, and used as the basis of other music related projects. GitHub repo.

danigb

Fancy-ANSI: Convert ANSI Text to HTML â€” If, for some reason, you want to convert text with ANSI escape codes into HTML.. Lots of examples on the homepage. GitHub repo.

Andres Morey

Dioma: Dependency Injection Container for Vanilla JS and TS â€” No decorators, no annotations, no magic, no dependencies â€“ you just add the static scope property to your class and use inject to get an instance.

Eugene Daragan

svelte-zoomable-circles: Svelte Component for Browsing Hierarchical Data â€” A Svelte component for displaying and browsing hierarchical data using zoomable circles. Live demo.

Tyler Berbert

  • VineJS 2.0 â€“ Form data validation library for Node.js.

  • PGlite 0.1.1 â€“ Lightweight Postgres packaged as WASM into a TypeScript library for the browser, Node.js, Bun and Deno. Now supports Postgres array types.

  • TS-Pattern 5.1 â€“ Pattern matching library with smart type inference.

  • ical.js 2.0 â€“ Parser for ICS (RFC5545) and vCard (RFC6350) data.

  • Minimatch 9.0.4 â€“ Glob matching function â€“ used by npm itself.

  • vue-tel-input 9.0 â€“ Telephone number input for Vue. (Demo.)

  • OverlayScrollbars 2.7 â€“ JS custom scrollbar plugin.

  • Octokit.js 3.2 â€“ 'Batteries-included' GitHub SDK.

#â€‹681 â€” March 28, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

JavaScript Visualized: Promise Execution â€” A helpful diagrammed and animated article, coupled with an (optional) 8-minute video, that goes into how promises work and are scheduled behind the scenes. Itâ€™s useful to have a good mental model of these mechanics, given promises form the basis of asynchronous functions in JavaScript.

Lydia Hallie

â–¶  Node.js: A Documentary of Its Origin Story â€” It's an hour long, but this documentary covers the history of Node particularly well, including how everything brewed up to the io.js fork of 2014. Easter weekend watching, perhaps?

Honeypot

Learn Advanced JavaScript Performance Optimization â€” Garbage collection, memory profiling, data structures like sets and arrays, and event loop management. Learn performance-driven programming, preparing you to write blazingly fast and efficient code!

Frontend Masters sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • The Node.js Technical Steering Committee has confirmed there's no intention to remove npm from the main Node distribution.

  • Is Bun Windows Yet? No, but Bun 1.1, which will support Windows, is supposedly just four days away..

  • An example of a simple, yet useful, Web Component in a single GitHub Gist.

  • The RedwoodJS framework now supports React Server Components too, as an alternative to its traditional GraphQL-based approach.

  • RunJS Play is a neat Web-based JavaScript playground that shows instant live feedback alongside each line.

  • Vercel now fully supports Node.js 20 for both builds and functions.

RELEASES:

  • VitePress 1.0 â€“ Powerful static site generator.

  • Neutralinojs 5.1 â€“ Alternative cross-platform desktop app framework.

  • Babylon.js 7.0 â€“ Powerful game & 3D rendering engine. No official release post yet, but expected later today.

  • Radix Themes 3.0 â€“ Powerful frontend component library.

  • Node.js v20.12.0 (LTS) and Node v18.20.0 (LTS).

  • Deno 1.42.0, Vite 5.2, TypeChat 0.1, Chromatic 3.

ğŸ“’ Articles & Tutorials

A Look at ECMAScript's Iterator Helper Methods â€” The proposal is several years old, but now at stage 3 in TC39, Iterator Helpers are being implemented and ship with V8 12.2/Chrome 122. The helpers are functions like .map, .filter, .take and .forEach and are made available to any object with Iterator.prototype in its prototype chain.

Rezvan Mahdavi Hezaveh (V8)

Introducing Waku's â€œPages Routerâ€ â€” Waku is an interesting minimal server-side React framework and itâ€™s now also bringing a minimal API to the modern React server components era: â€œMaking a Waku site is now as simple as making a few files and folders in the ./src/pages directoryâ€..

Sophia Andren

Transformational Auth & Identity | Userfront â€” Userfront is an auth & identity platform that transforms your business to serve free, freemium and enterprise customers.

Userfront sponsor

What You Need to Know About Modern CSS â€” A guide with a list of the newest additions to CSS (think nesting, view transitions, :has(), etc). JS plays an occasional role too, whether by enhancing or polyfilling modern CSS features.

Chris Coyier

Building a Micro HTMX SSR Framework â€” Matteo builds on an earlier tutorial about creating a â€˜movie quotesâ€™ app by exploring an alternative backend stack to use, based upon Fastify, Vite and HTMX.

Matteo Collina

Meet Angularâ€™s New output() API â€” Outputs allow component authors to emit values to parent components.
Paul Gschwendtner (Google)

We Rewrote our React App in Svelte in Three Weeks
Dusty Phillips

How to Use the Web Bluetooth API
Confidence Okoghenun

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Trix 2.1: A Clean, Rich WYSIWYG Editor for the Web â€” A WYSIWYG editor developed by the folks at 37signals (known as the birthplace of Ruby on Rails). Itâ€™s used in their Basecamp and HEY apps, so is about as stress tested as you can get. GitHub repo.

37signals

Meet the Future of Data Delivery with Hasura DDN â€” Join us April 16 for the unveiling of Hasura DDN. Create a unified, composable API, instantly and with no maintenance.
